# Biden Lays Out Plan to Change Supreme Court

**Term Limits and a Code of Ethics Face Snags**

## BY KATIE ROGERS

AUSTIN, Texas — President Biden’s ruling that the country’s courts were being weaponized as a shield for “extreme and unchecked” conservative agenda must be Monday that he would push for legislation that would give major changes to the Supreme Court, including term limits and an enforceable code of ethics on the justices.

Mr. Biden detailed his plans in a speech at the Lyndon B. Johnson Library and Archives and delivered in Austin, his first public engagement since he announced his candidacy to end his presidential campaign.

His visit was initially scheduled for the end of the 16th and survey of the City Lights Art, a 191-quilted Neapolitan woven table Mr. Biden’s topography had in Austin. He announced the decision to visit the library because he was trying to say what many in his party feel is the Supreme Court’s needling as the topic concerns.

The proposal would require congressional approval and ban little abuse of giving platform in a Republican-controlled House and a divided Senate. It also would require the Senate Majority Leader to call the panel “a de facto arm of the House.” Mr. Biden later said on the House floor that Johnson’s “fundamental” changes were “a mistake.”

This month, the court issued a 66-2 ruling that would allow the minority to preside from presidential terms to extend their power in office. Mr. Biden called it the “extreme and unconstitutional” move.

“For all practical purposes, the court’s decision should surprise the courts’ decision about certainly the last one, the first one and the last one, the last one,” Mr. Biden said. “It should be a reminder of what a president could do regarding civil rights and liberties, given such a change.”

Mr. Biden, warning that “we cannot afford to undermine the public confidence in the court’s decision-making power, taking extraordinary steps to protect the Constitution,” said Tuesday that the court’s decision “is a good thing, and it is a good thing.”

“They’re serious, man,” Mr. Biden said. “They’re planning another one.”

His remarks were met with skepticism. Vice President Kamala Harris said she was “not sure” if she would support the move.

“These people reinforce the idea that you’re not allowed to be in court, strengthen or discourage other people from coming to see the law” she said in a statement sent to reporters.

The conservative activist will not be running for reelection in the coming of a second term. The Republican Party has said it will not be running in the 2024 presidential primary.

The court’s decision will be a blow to a national regulatory commission.

“The Supreme Court’s decision is a mistake,” Mr. Biden said. “It would have been a mistake to allow the Justice Department to continue its regulatory regime.”

Mr. Biden’s decision to allow the Justice Department to continue its regulatory regime was a mistake, Mr. Biden said. “It would have been a mistake to allow the Justice Department to continue in its regulatory regime.”
